newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bomb damages flat of U.N. policeman in Bosnia.
newsitem.headline: Bomb damages flat of U.N. policeman in Bosnia.

text.p: A bomb damaged the apartment of an international police officer early on Friday morning in the latest Bosnian Serb retaliatory attack over a NATO swoop on indicted war criminals.
U.N. spokesman Alun Roberts said the sleeping officer was not injured in the blast in Gradiska, about 50 km (30 miles) north of Banja Luka, in Bosnia's Serb entity.
"There was quite a bit of damage to the balcony and living room windows," Roberts told Reuters.
The explosion was the fifth in as many days aimed at peacekeepers or civilian international officials. In a sixth incident, a U.S. soldier was slightly hurt in an attack with a sickle.
Roberts said the wave of minor explosions "appear to be a form of low-level intimidation" in retaliation for the NATO arrest operation last week.

Serb nationalist leaders were outraged over the swoop on two Serbs charged with war crimes by a U.N. tribunal. One suspect was seized and extradited, and another was shot dead when he resisted British soldiers trying to arrest him.
Roberts also said posters had been plastered around the region with a picture of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb president who is also wanted by the tribunal for war crimes.
Below Karadzic's picture were the words: "Don't touch him - he means peace".
